body: Paradigm: Multi-paradigm: object-oriented, imperative, functional, reflective
Concurrency: Supports multi-threading and concurrent programming with fibers
Ruby Info.description: Provides general information about the Ruby programming language.

body: # To run this program, use: `ruby filename.rb`
Ruby Entry Point.description: Creates the entry point of a Ruby application.

body: #   - Rakefile: Provides automated tasks like database migrations, running tests, etc.
#   - config.ru: Rack configuration file for Rack-based applications.
#   - models/: Contains the models for an MVC framework.
#   - controllers/: Contains the controllers for an MVC framework.
#   - views/: Contains the views for an MVC framework.
#   - Database related files, like migrations and seeds.
#   - Library code that can be reused in other projects.
#   - Static files like images, stylesheets, and JavaScript files.
#   - Test files, following the naming convention of the testing framework (e.g., RSpec uses `spec`).
# - This structure can vary, especially with different frameworks like Rails, Sinatra, etc.
# - Ensure that the project structure aligns with the conventions of the used framework.
Ruby Project Structure (High-Level).description: Explains a high-level project structure for Ruby.

Ruby Mathematical Operators.description: Lists the mathematical operators in Ruby.

Ruby Boolean Operators.description: Lists the boolean operators in Ruby.

Ruby Type Check.description: Gets the type of a variable in Ruby.

Ruby This Type Check.description: Gets the class of the variable in the clipboard in Ruby.

body: # Check if two variables have the same type:
Ruby Type Comparison.description: Compares the types of two variables in Ruby.

body: # - Can be unpredictable, especially with loose equality (==).
# - Be aware of implicit conversions and use explicit conversions when necessary for clarity and control.
Ruby is a dynamically typed language.
Some common types in Ruby include:
- NilClass: Represents the absence of a value
- Class, Module: Class and module objects
Ruby Types.description: Lists some common types in Ruby.

body: # Ruby uses true and false for boolean values.
Ruby Boolean Type.description: Ruby uses true and false for boolean values.

body: # Ruby does not have a separate char type; use String instead.
Ruby Character Type.description: Ruby does not have a separate char type; use String instead.

Ruby Map Type.description: The Ruby Hash type, equivalent to a map.

Ruby List Type.description: The Ruby Array type, equivalent to a list.

Ruby Date Now.description: Gets the current date in Ruby.

body: # Ruby is a dynamically typed language.
Ruby Dynamic Type.description: Ruby is a dynamically typed language.

body: # - Ruby is dynamically typed, so there is no explicit type declaration.
# - Variables are created when you first assign a value to them.
# - Variables can be reassigned to different types.
# - Ruby does not have direct equivalents to 'var', 'let', or 'const'.
# - Use descriptive variable names to improve code readability.
# Note: Ruby is dynamically typed; explicit type annotations are not used.
Ruby Create Typed Variable.description: Creates a variable in Ruby with a comment about dynamic typing.
